review.title: Latent Bayesian melding for integrating individual and population models
review.abstract: In many statistical problems, a more coarse-grained model may be suitable for population-level behaviour, whereas a more detailed model is appropriate for accurate modelling of individual behaviour. This raises the question of how to integrate both types of models. Methods such as posterior regularization follow the idea of generalized moment matching, in that they allow matching expectations between two models, but sometimes both models are most conveniently expressed as latent variable models. We propose latent Bayesian melding, which is motivated by averaging the distributions over populations statistics of both the individual-level and the population-level models under a logarithmic opinion pool framework. In a case study on electricity disaggregation, which is a type of single-channel blind source separation problem, we show that latent Bayesian melding leads to significantly more accurate predictions than an approach based solely on generalized moment matching.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: These two types of modeling represent different types of information, so it is natural to want to combine them. A recent line of research in machine learning has explored the idea of incorporating constraints into Bayesian models that are difficult to cooperate in standard distributions. These methods, which include post distributions, tend to be very different from good models of individuals. As another example, in social network analysis, simple models such as the preferred access model [3] can replicate aggregated network statistics such as grade distributions, while predicting whether two individuals have a connection, a social networking site could well use a classifier with many traits of each person's prehistory. Of course, each model of an individual implies a model of the population, but models whose goal is to model model individuals tend to be necessarily more detailed. These two types of modeling represent different types of information, so naturally they want to combine it with each other.

sections.heading: 4 Related methods
sections.text: We are now discussing possible links between Bayesian merger (BM) and other related methods. Recently, machine learning has proposed methods that allow constant (or posterior) regulation (PR) [9], measurement learning [16] and the general expectation criterion [18]. These methods share the common idea that Bayesian models (or posterior distributions) are limited by some observations or measurements to obtain a least distorted distribution, the idea being that the system we model is too complex and unobservable, and that we therefore have limited prior information. To alleviate this problem, we assume that we can obtain some observations of the system in some way, e.g. through experiments, these observations could be the averages of the functions of the variables, and these observations could then guide the modeling of the system.

sections.text: In the energy breakdown, we get a time series of energy consumption values from a sensor. We consider the energy measured in watt-hours to be read from a household's electricity meter, which is denoted by Y = (Y1, Y2, · ·, YT), with Yt-R +. sections.heading: 5.2 Population modelling of summary statistics
sections.text: In the energy aggregation, it is useful to provide a summary of the energy consumption for users that can be captured by these consumption data. For example, it would be useful to show the total energy they have consumed for their appliances in a single day, the duration in which each appliance has been in use, and the number of times they have used these appliances. As there is already data on the typical use of different appliances, we assume that we have measured some time series from different houses for many days, because we can collect them from public data sets, such as the data verified in [4]. We can then empirically obtain the distributions of these statistics.

sections.text: In this section we apply the proposed model to the disaggregation problem. We compare the new approach with AFHMM + PR [26] using the statistics τ described in Section 5.2. sections.heading: 7.2 UK-DALE data
sections.text: In the previous section, we trained the model with the HES data and applied the models to different houses of the same dataset. A more realistic situation is to train the model in one dataset, and apply the model to another dataset, because it is unrealistic to get the application level data from every household on which the system is used. In this section, we use the HES data to train the model parameters of the AFHMM, and model the distribution of the summary statistics. We apply the models to the UK-DALE dataset, which was also collected by UK households to make the predictions. There are five houses in UK-DALE, and all of them have network measurements and the individual device measurements. All network measurements were all evaluated in the 6 seconds and some of them were provided at a higher rate.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions
sections.text: We have proposed a latent Bayesian merger approach to integrate population information with latent variables into individual models and applied the approach to energy breakdown problems; the new approach was evaluated by applying it to two real electricity datasets; the latent Bayesian merger approach was compared to the posterior regulation approach (a case of the Bayesian merger approach) and AFHMM. Both the LBM and PR exhibit significantly lower errors than the baseline method; LBM improves over PR in predicting the duration and number of cycles; both methods were similar in NDE and the SAE errors.
